title: Where in 2023 to find some of the best returns on bonds in two decades, according to Goldman Sachs
text:
Should their forecast comes to fruition, U.S. corporate bonds would tally some of their best total returns in the past two decades, while also wiping out the historically bad performance this year for U.S. junk bonds. It also would put a significant dent in the more than negative 17% total return estimated for investment-grade corporate bonds in 2022.

Investors in U.S. bonds have been working to claw back from a historically bad year as the Federal Reserve has dramatically raised rates to help combat inflation that has been slow to retreat from its highest levels in four decades.

Higher benchmark bond yields BX:TMUBMUSD10Y help, with investment-grade bond yields recently touching the highest since 2009 at near 5.6% and junk-bond yields closer to 8.7%.

Bond yields in November pulled back slightly from their highest levels of the year as investors gauged whether signs of slowing inflation potentially might lead to a slower pace of Fed rate hikes, or even cuts down the road.

Stocks rallied earlier in November, but have given back some of those gains as Fed officials continued to warn that rates could end up higher in this tightening cycle than initially anticipated, and stay high, which could lead to a prolonged period of some of the highest borrowing costs for businesses and households since the aftermath of the 2008 global financial crisis.

See:Fed's Daly says financial markets are acting like interest rates are much higher than they actually are

Goldman's credit team, led by Lotfi Karoui, said the Fed's inflation battle still could cloud the fortunes of weaker companies that need financing because "the paradox of a 'softish' landing outcome for the U.S. economy also implies a higher-than-average risk of a payment shock among over-leveraged and rates-sensitive borrowers, and thus constrains investors' appetite to aggressively move down the quality spectrum."

Individuals often gain exposure to corporate bonds through exchange-traded funds, the biggest of which are the iShares iBoxx $ Investment Grade Corporate Bond ETF LQD, the iShares iBoxx $ High Yield Corporate Bond ETF HYG and SPDR Bloomberg High Yield Bond ETF JNK, which were up for November, but down about 15% to 20% on the year through Monday, according to FactSet.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was down about 7.1% for the year on Monday, while the S&P 500 index SPX was off 17% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP was 29.4% lower.

See: Favor bonds as stocks look expensive amid Wall Street's 'timid approach' to earnings revisions, says Morgan Stanley

Where in 2023 to find some of the best returns on bonds in two decades, according to Goldman Sachs
